Logrolling is illegal in most state constitutions for a reason – something public choice theorists do not discuss. In the mid 1800s the evils of logrolling were important topics. Further, you do not discuss the 1970 Legislative Reorganization Act which made all committee votes public – increasing the opportunity to 'logroll.' But recall that if logrolling can occur, so can bribery and intimidation (another topic you leave out entirely). It would be nice to see this video updated to support recent research on the profound problems with congressional transparency.

Crash Course, I love your videos, will continue watching them and don't expect them to be perfect.  But with all due respect, one MAJOR failure of the "Government and Politics" series is the frankly factually incorrect assertion they make (in this video and at least one other) that there is "no evidence" of the phenomenon of money influencing elected officials' voting habits.  To the contrary, Princeton and Northwestern Universities conducted a joint study on this very issue in which they analyzed roughly 1,800 policy positions over a period of approximately 20 years.  The study ultimately concluded that while political campaign contributions have a direct impact on the laws that get passed in Washington, public opinion has little or no bearing, in this respect.  It is what it is guys and while I agree that there is such a thing as being too cynical, sometimes we do just have to call a spade a spade in the interests of arriving at truth.

I really bugs me that these Government and Politic videos aren't very popular on this channel, because it gives good insight into most peoples view on politics. 

Yes politics is confusing, annoying, and downright stressful because of all the shit-throwing that the different parties do to each other, but if we want anything to change we HAVE to pay attention and hold our leaders accountable.

You cannot gripe about the state your country is in if you refuse to learn anything about it and stay informed on current events.

What is he talking about here?  There was a study done on the whole money in politics deal, and they found that the average person has next to no influence on how things are currently run.  Here: http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=9354310  *shakes head*
NO PRESIDENCY CHAPTER?

It's simply a non-partisan description on congressional decision making for the purpose of education.  Did you miss the puns he made in the video?  For example, "3 things you'll need to know to pass that test", or "for the sake of studying purposes, I'm going to 'simplify' these examples..."  This is an introductory video to let the majority of people who are not interested in politics help understand basic principles on how the system works.  It is an attempt to be informative to an audience that may not have ever known or cared to know.  This is a great platform and new medium to reach a new audience who may not have not heard this information otherwise.  This Channel is clearly not designed for you, nor for me.  But,  I love the Crash Course Channel and want to support the Vlog Brothers John and Hank Green, because they are doing great things and are really making a difference in the world.  You want to hear lobbying history, cloakroom dealings, SuperPacs, the 112th do-nothing congress, gerrymandering, etc.  Then change the channel, listen to a political podcast, or read a book.  In fact want to take the initiative, meet with your congressman, local town council, call your state or U.S. Senator, write a letter to congress, start a petition, run for a local office (many run reelection unopposed), or anything else than complain about an educational channel clearly designed as a survey course video.  Not a 200 or higher level college course on American government in which you read Kennan's book on American Diplomacy, or Of The People Volume I, by Oxford University Press.  I am trying to be sincere and by no means which any ill, I wanted to just express a point.  Good day, Sir.

The day of Congressional response to public opinion is dead. And so is the thought of public pressure upon Congressional delegations being relevant to the incumbents.

Congress now has a long and well documented track record of listening to, and acting according to interests of, corporate and large private campaign donors. Modern elections are all based upon the incumbents being able to build a large enough campaign fund to saturate the media and disseminate their propaganda.

This works because a large segment of the voters exhibit extremely short term memory, forgetting the incumbents' track records and actual performance, replacing the reality with the message of the campaign literature.

Neither party is innocent of this propagandizing, and both parties know that the voters have extremely short term memories. We have literally become an electorate which casts its ballot based upon who was the loudest candidate and which one we heard last. There are times that it appears the one with the most outrageous actions gets all the attention.

This also has the unfortunate effect of burying the independent candidate, as they generally cannot build a large enough campaign war chest - no national party to conduct an expensive media blitz on their behalf, no carefully constructed PACs supporting them which shield the donors from public view, no corporate or special interest funded events, etc. - to match the cacophony a candidate backed by one of the 2 national parties can achieve.

Cynical viewpoint? Definitely! The result of 50 years voting, and actively following national politics since the JFK/Nixon debates.
I hope at some point you examine other countries systems of government.

This is almost laughable. He completely left out the effect elections have on congressional decision-making, especially in the House of Representatives where there are two year terms. What's more, that's where the money in politics has centered itself of late. Not conservative enough? Sheldon Adelson or David Koch will drop a few million dollars into your primary competitor's SuperPAC so he/she can ad blast you into eternity.

From Day 1, congressmen have to raise hundreds of thousands of dollars, for senators millions, to get re-elected. He's correct that there are no fedora wearing bagmen paying money for votes, but special interests greatly influence elections and enhance their access by keeping politicians friendly to their causes elected and indebted to their financial backing.

I'm in contact with legislators regularly. I think, at least in Lansing, that mostly everyone I've met in the House and Senate are well-meaning, even if they don't all agree (some go into the legislature with the idea that the system is broken and leave with the same idea, since their cynical attitude breaks the system for them alone). My experience with lobbyists is also more positive than the stereotype. The one I worked with focused mainly on keeping her clients updated on relevant legislation and informing the legislators about issues that most of them had no idea even existed. It's easy to form an opinion about people you've never met. Go to your capitol and meet with your [state] representatives, they'd be ecstatic to meet with you and talk to you about the issues you have.

You tried to make it sound as if congress was innocent of corruption and downplayed the level of influence that money from lobbyists has on political decisions. Yes, it's cynical to assume that everything congress does is evil, but it's not unfounded cynicism. Groups like Citizens United have a huge impact on the decision making process mainly because of the 'benefits' they provide to their lackey politicians. The so-called representatives of the people are easily swayed to vote for legislature that will benefit their sponsors even if said legislature harms the people, the environment or the country. They'll do anything to create the right political environment for their sponsors in order to keep the cash flowing into their pockets.

By the way, there is some empirical evidence that money influences congressmen more than voters. It may not be a smoking gun, but it can't be ignored. 

http://scholar.princeton.edu/sites/default/files/mgilens/files/gilens_and_page_2014_-testing_theories_of_american_politics.doc.pdf

http://visual.ly/how-money-won-congress?utm_source=visually_embed

http://www.cracked.com/article_21786_6-ways-government-corruption-way-weirder-than-you-think.html

For the first time, I am disappointed in Crash Course. First, there are numerous examples of money affecting politicians' decisions. Whether it is when a politician changes their stance on an issue and conveniently receiving campaign donations from a group representing that issue, or when it is discovered that a lobbying (special interest) group blatantly writes a bill which numerous politicians try to pass off as their own (recent incidents like ALEC, or even Citibank writing Wall Street bills), there are too many examples of money affecting politics to count- yet Crash Course would have us believe that there is no link? Or that, at best, they "convince" politicians to "strike" part of a bill indirectly? Downplaying the effects of money and special interests in politics is doing your viewers a disservice. If anything, you should have downplayed the role that satisfying their constituents plays in politicians' decision-making (even though you label that reality as "cynical"). Which leads me to my second point, which is that politicians now often run unopposed, or in districts that are so gerrymandered that it is impossible for them to lose. You claim that politicians respond to the will of their voters, and that may have once been the case, but it is no longer the case. Politicians are constantly voting against their constituents' interests, and often even against their explicitly expressed wishes. They are able to get away with this now, largely due to the facts I just mentioned- running unopposed, or in gerrymandered districts. This rose-colored spin of the real-world facts disappointed me severely.
P.S. I know many may want to point to the Tea Party as an example of politicians who don't respond to voters being ousted in their gerrymandered districts'  primaries, but the lesson still holds for two reasons: 1) the Tea Party was financially backed by big money (again showing the influence of moneyed special interests), and 2) many of the those that were voted into office due to their promises to be different than establishment republicans ended up voting against those promises. (That said, I am not one of their supporters, so I wasn't disappointed when they broke those ridiculous promises, yet it still shows that money is more important in modern politics than the will of the voters).

Individual constituents rarely have enough money to sway national politicians to their side on a particular issue.  Special interest groups (PACs, Super PACs, 501x,y,z,'s) provide the vast majority of campaign funds for US Senate and US Representatives.  Since incumbents need so much money to pay for their re-election, much of their time and effort is spent raising money.  According to MSNBC, In 2008, the average cost of winning a House seat was about $1.1 million and $6.5 million for a Senate seat.  So, when they are preparing to vote on an issue relevant to a special interest group, most politicians listen to that special interests lobbyist and may not even meet with their constituents.
